thread.title: Lee claims the Western Mass D-III golf title, Devyn Olds is co-medalist
thread.title_full: Lee claims the Western Mass D-III golf title, Devyn Olds is co-medalist

author:
Howard Herman
hherman@berkshireeagle.com @howardherman on Twitter
title: Lee claims the Western Mass D-III golf title, Devyn Olds is co-medalist
text:
Posted: 10/19/2015 10:58:29 PM EDT Updated: 10/20/2015 05:42:30 AM EDT 
The last two years have been a case of close but no cigar for the Lee golf team. Two years ago, the Wildcats came up short in a championship bid and last year were four shots from qualifying from the MIAA Division III state championship. On Monday, the Wildcats erased both of those marks. 
Devyn Olds shared medalist honors with Turners Falls' Ryan Lenois with scores of 78, and the Wildcats earned a decisive victory over Monson to claim the 2015 Western Massachusetts Division III championship in the tournament at The Ranch in Southwick. The Wildcats finished with a score of 345 to Monson's 353. 
"It feels fantastic," Olds said after his co-medalist round. "I knew we were the underdog for this. We were feeling confident coming in today." 
"This is truly amazing," freshman Thomas Fraser said. "Our whole team did really good." 
Fraser was an eighth grader on the Wildcat team that finished fifth a year ago. 
Defending champion Caleb Farnham of Hopkins Academy shot an 83 on Monday, five strokes behind Olds and Lenois. 
Neither of last year's state teams, champion Pioneer Valley and runner-up St. Mary's, qualified for the state tournament. 
St. Joseph golfer Cody Tynan shot an 86 and his score was the cutoff to qualify for the state tournament. 
The Wildcats and Tynan will head to Cape Cod next week for the state Division III tournament. The event will be held at the Cummaqiuid Golf Club in Yarmouth Port. Advertisement 
Lee coach Matt Carlino is in his third season as the Wildcat mentor, and he said he couldn't be happier with the result. 
"We have great kids. We have young kids coming up too," he said after the tournament. "We're pretty happy. I'm happy for the kids. They deserve it." 
The tournament itself started 90 minutes later than scheduled because overnight frost impacted the course. The 18 holes might have thawed out a bit, but the players ... well, that's another story. 
"It was cold and tough conditions," said Carlino. "There were higher scores because of the conditions. [The course] played tougher." 
While olds and freshman Thomas Fraser, one of the runners-up at last week's Berkshire Classic, both finished in the top five, it was a score at the back of the Lee board that helped propel the Wildcats to the Cape. 
With two scores of 100 or better in the board, the Wildcats got a 90 from senior David Belanger, and that helped propel the Wildcats into the lead. 
"I'm so happy for David," said Carlino. "It's his senior year. He came through and sealed the deal for us." 
A year ago, Olds was fifth in the tournament at Franconia. The conditions were a bit better then and while the score may not have completely reflected the play, the Wildcat said he was happy with his performance. 
"It was windy and cold. I was hitting really good shots all day," said Olds, who added he had only one three-putt all day. "I didn't use the driver much. I was using my 4-iron [more]." 
The Wildcats will be accompanied to the Cape by St. Joe's Tynan, whose 86 earned him a spot in the state championship. 
"I thought I hit the ball good" Monday, he said after his round. "I was in trouble a little more than I would have liked." 
Tynan, like everyone else, had to adjust to grees that were hard and quick. He said the greens didn't hold too many of his shots. 
"It was cold, but I'm pretty happy with my score," he said. "Eighty-six in this weather, I'll take it.'' 
As will the Wildcats, who got to bring home the gold trophy. 
"Our whole season, we kept working as a team and we got better every match," said Fraser. "I knew we had a shot at this." 
——— 
Team totals 1. Lee 345; 2. Monson 353; 3. Hopkins Academy 363; 4. Smith Academy 372; 5. St. Mary 376; 6. Pioneer Valley 380; 7. McCann Tech 392; 8. Lenox 400; 9. Franklin Tech 401. 
Top 10 finishers 1. Devyn Olds, Lee and Ryan Lenois, Turners Falls 78; 3. Jacob Willis, Pioneer Valley 82; 4. Caleb Farnham, Hopkins 83; 5. Thomas Fraser, Lee 85; 6. Cody Tynan, St. Joseph 86; 7. Nick Kratovil, Monson and Daniel Cavanaugh, Smith Academy 87; 9. Spencer Butterfield, Hopkins, Jacob Gordan,Monson, Luke Wittenburg, St. Mary and John Soltys, Ware 88. 
Local team results Lee — Devyn Olds 78, Thomas Fraser 85, Bryce Whalen 92, Hunter Roosa 100, Colin Finnegan 104, David Belanger 90. Lenox — Kevin Coakley 98, Noah Hunter 102, Lucy Schwartz 102, Ricky Armstrong 98, John Fontaine 111, Matthew Shields 104. McCann Tech — Bradley Tatro 93, Ryan Meehan 110, Cole Kratz 96, Jake Tower 111, Brian Boudreau 93, Tristan McNay 133. Contact Howard Herman at 413-496-6253.
